the video introduces trigonometry basics focusing on right triangle trigonometry, explaining the concept of SOHCAHTOA and the six trigonometric functions. It covers finding missing sides, special triangles, and calculating trigonometric values using sine, cosine, and tangent.   Key moments: 00:02 Understanding right triangle trigonometry involves knowing the three sides of a triangle: opposite, adjacent, and hypotenuse. SOHCAHTOA helps relate these sides to the six trigonometric functions sine, cosine, tangent, secant, cosecant, and cotangent.           -SOHCAHTOA relates the sides of a right triangle to the trigonometric functions sine, cosine, and tangent.           -Special right triangles like 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, and 7-24-25 have whole number ratios that simplify calculations. 05:05 By understanding SOHCAHTOA, one can easily calculate the values of sine, cosine, tangent, cosecant, secant, and cotangent in right triangles.           -Using the 8-15-17 triangle to find the missing side and trigonometric values.           -Applying the Pythagorean theorem to confirm the missing side in a 3-4-5 triangle. 10:09 Trigonometric functions like tangent, cosine, and sine can be used to find missing side lengths in right triangles by relating sides to angles.           -Using tangent to find a missing side length by dividing opposite over adjacent sides.           -Applying cosine to determine a side length by dividing adjacent over hypotenuse.           -Utilizing sine function to calculate a side length by dividing opposite over hypotenuse. 15:13 To find missing angles in right triangles, use trigonometric functions like tangent, cosine, and sine. Calculate these angles using inverse trigonometric functions.           -Using tangent to find missing angles in right triangles.           -Applying cosine to calculate angles in right triangles.           -Utilizing sine function to determine missing angles in right triangles.

Imagine you have a triangle like a slice of pizza. The longest side, opposite the right angle, is like the crust.  - Sin (sine) : If you want to know how tall your pizza slice is compared to the crust, you look at sin. - Cos (cosine) : If you want to know how long the bottom part of your pizza slice is, right where it's widest, compared to the crust, you look at cos. - Tan (tangent) : If you want to compare how tall your pizza slice is to how wide it is at the bottom, you look at tan.  For the other three:  - Csc (cosecant) : It’s like asking, "If my pizza slice height was 1, how long would the crust be?" It's the opposite idea of sin. - Sec (secant) : It’s like saying, "If the bottom part of my pizza slice was 1, how long would the crust be?" The opposite idea of cos. - Cot (cotangent) : It’s like comparing the bottom width to the height, but the opposite way of tan.
